results.title: Cyberdelia
results.credit_line:
Steve Spangaro, director
Mike Collins, associate director
Milena Romanin, production manager
Susan King, interviews and research
Based on an original concept by Adem Jaffers
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
Cyberdelia is a visceral encounter with the aesthetic and ideals of Melbourne underground cyber artists at the confluence of analogue and digital creative practice in 1991.

In blending artist interviews and works, this magazine style documentary explores visions of personal and cultural enhancement through transformative digital technologies. The imminent fusion of spirituality with technology; flesh with machine and psychedelia with cybernetics is confidently proclaimed.

Cyberdelia is a visual and aural feast with the film-makers channelling the post-modern mischief and transcendental yearnings of the ‘cyberdelic’ movement to radical stylistic effect. Stunning cyber artist works are liberally leveraged as both feature material and interstitial fodder. Low-budget analogue video editing and compositing tools are pushed to the limit while artist on-camera interviews are staged in bizarre fashion so as to maintain the feel of a ‘trip documentary’ from start to finish.

Produced for broadcast on community television station RMITV, Cyberdelia stretches the boundaries of arts documentary to portray the brazen idealism and micro-processor powered creativity of these pre World Wide Web visionaries.

Artists: Acid Death Bed, Misha Hollenbach, Troy Innocent (Cyber Dada), Natalie Jeremijenko, Adem Jaffers (Neuro), Jeff Jaffers (Third Eye), Dale Nason (Cyber Dada), Ollie Olsen (Third Eye) Captain ROM, Stelarc, Gus Till (Third Eye), Julian Wong, Christopher Wright and Max Q.

Cyberdelia was generously donated to ACMI by Cyberdelia Productions.

results.title: The Dame Was Loaded for DOS
results.creator_credit: Philips Interactive Media, Inc. and Beam Software
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. Two CD-ROM, CD case insert and manual in 2 CD capacity jewel case
results.brief_description:
A hardboiled detective, femme Fatales, missing people and money. The Dame was Loaded has all the hardboiled elements of film noir and is just as cinematic.

Created using innovative Full Motion Video (FMV) technology, which was developed in-house at Beam Software, this point-and-click adventure incorporated real footage of actors that players interact with to solve the mystery. At the time when computer graphics were limited, PMV games tried to generate empathy in players by putting them in the protagonist’s point of view and presenting other characters as real people in a fully realised game world.

When it was made it was the largest multimedia production in Australia, with game developers collaborating closely with actors and film crews, who used iconic Melbourne landmarks as settings like the art-deco former police headquarters on Russell Street.

results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. Two CD-ROM, CD case insert and manual in 2 CD capacity jewel case

results.title: Aussie Rules Footy for NES
results.material_description: Cartridge videogame. Cartridge, cartridge sleeve and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description:
Aussie Rules Footy was Beam Software’s first Nintendo Entertainment System (NES) sports game developed exclusively for the Australian market. Despite simple controls, its clever design captured the high-energy, competitive spirit of the sport, featuring spectacular high marking and pushing other players out from under a mark.

It also contained Beam’s signature sense of humour. Though voice samples were unusual in NES games of the era, Aussie Rules Footy used voice lines like the deadpan umpire’s “out of bounds on the full”, which complemented the droll text-based commentary between quarters.

Despite the official AFL logo on the box, it’s unlikely the game was licensed, which could be why the 18 playable teams don’t match their real-life counterparts, with curious inclusions like Darwin, Canberra and Hobart.

It also contained Beam’s signature sense of humour. Though voice samples were unusual in NES games of the era, Aussie Rules Footy used voice lines like the deadpan umpire’s “out of bounds on the full”, which complemented the droll text-based commentary between quarters.

Despite the official AFL logo on the box, it’s unlikely the game was licensed, which could be why the 18 playable teams don’t match their real-life counterparts, with curious inclusions like Darwin, Canberra and Hobart.

results.title: Cate Blanchett: Screen Worlds Spotlight interview
results.brief_description: An interview with actor Cate Blanchett for Screen Worlds at ACMI. Cate Blanchett is an actor who has multiple awards including Golden Globe and Academy awards, and is well known for her roles in films such as “Elizabeth”, “Carol” and “I’m Not There”.
results.description: An interview with actor Cate Blanchett for Screen Worlds at ACMI. Cate Blanchett is an actor who has multiple awards including Golden Globe and Academy awards, and is well known for her roles in films such as “Elizabeth”, “Carol” and “I’m Not There”.
description_for_label: An interview with actor Cate Blanchett for Screen Worlds at ACMI. Cate Blanchett is an actor who has multiple awards including Golden Globe and Academy awards, and is well known for her roles in films such as “Elizabeth”, “Carol” and “I’m Not There”.

results.title: Krome Studios: Screen Worlds Spotlight interview
results.brief_description: An interview with Krome Studios for Screen Worlds at ACMI. Krome Studios is a video game development studio most well known for their “Ty the Tasmanian Tiger” games.

results.title: Sue Smith and John Alsop : Screen Worlds Spotlight interview
results.brief_description: An interview with screenwriters Sue Smith and John Alsop for Screen Worlds at ACMI. Sue Smith and John Alsop are screenwriters and playwrights who have collaborated on productions such as “My Brother Jack”, “Brides of Christ”, “Bordertown” and “The Leaving of Liverpool”.

results.title: Animal Logic: Screen Worlds Spotlight interview
results.brief_description: An interview with Animal Logic for Screen Worlds at ACMI. Animal Logic is an animation and visual effects digital studio known for their role on films such as “Happy Feet”, “The Lego Movie” and “Peter Rabbit”.

results.title: Yoram Gross : Screen Worlds Spotlight interview
results.brief_description: An interview with producer Yoram Gross for Screen Worlds at ACMI. Yoram Gross founded the Yoram Gross Film Studio and was known for his work on animated films and TV series including “Blinky Bill”, the “Dot” series, and “The Magic Riddle”.
